**[Titre :]{.underline} Conserver l\'histoire de la conservation : un
modèle de données dynamique appliqué aux aires protégées de Madagascar**

[Résumé :]{.underline} Les données spatiales décrivant la délimitation
et les caractéristiques des aires protégées sont essentielles aux études
sur la conservation. La World Database on Protected Areas (WDPA)
constitue le référentiel international en la matière. Ce type de bases
inclut généralement les limites actuelles des aires protégées, ainsi que
leurs attributs tels que leur date de création, leur statut et leur
gestionnaire. Cette représentation statique entraîne une perte
importante d\'informations sur les états passés des aires protégées
lorsque leurs limites ou leurs caractéristiques ont évolué au fil du
temps. En l'absence de précisions temporelles explicites, la pratique
dominante parmi les chercheurs et analystes consiste à supposer que
frontières et caractéristiques sont restées inchangées depuis la date de
création. Cette hypothèse induit des erreurs et des biais lorsqu\'il
s\'agit d\'analyser l\'évolution des aires protégées ou évaluer leurs
impacts environnementaux et socioéconomiques. Dans cet article, nous
proposons un modèle de données dynamique appliqué à Madagascar, qui vise
à compléter la WDPA plutôt qu'à s'y substituer. Ce modèle explicite les
périodes de validité des informations disponibles dans la WDPA et
ajoute, pour chaque aire protégée, les états antérieurs documentés, y
compris pour celles qui ne figurent pas (ou plus) dans la base
internationale. Il intègre également, lorsque cela est pertinent, les
périmètres internes des aires protégées, en particulier ceux des zones
de protection stricte (noyaux durs), qui font l\'objet d\'un régime
spécifique de conservation. Nous publions ces données sous forme ouverte
sur un portail pérenne, accompagnées d'un protocole permettant de les
compléter ou de les corriger de manière itérative et collaborative.

**Title: Conserving the history of conservation: A dynamic data model
applied to Madagascar\'s protected areas (2000-2024)**

[Abstract:]{.underline} Protected areas spatial data, which includes
their location and characteristics, is an essential source for
conservation studies. National and international databases that provide
this information typically include the current boundaries of protected
areas, as well as their attributes such as creation date, status, and
manager. However, this data structure results in a significant loss of
information regarding past states of protected areas when their
boundaries or characteristics have changed over time. This practice
leads to erroneous results when using the data to analyze the evolution
of protected areas or evaluate their impact on the environment and
living conditions. In this article, we propose a data structure that
avoids this loss of information and the resulting analysis errors by
including each successive state of each protected area and specifying
the validity dates of this information. We publish this information for
Madagascar from 2000 to 2024 in the form of an open dataset accessible
to researchers and conservation professionals on a sustainable portal.
We examine a few emblematic studies in this country, demonstrating how
this new data structure allows for different and more reliable
conclusions regarding the importance of conservation in Madagascar.
Finally, we discuss the benefits of widespread adoption of this enriched
data structure by conservation specialists.

WDPA manual mentions:

\"\"\"

The 'Status Year' (STATUS_YR) field identifies the year in which a
site's current status (STATUS field) came into effect. It does not refer
to the year in which the data was updated in the WDPA or OECM database
(this information is available in the Source Table). If the Status is
'Proposed', the Status Year is the year the site was proposed. If the
Status is 'Designated', the Status Year is the year the site was
designated. Some geographies may have been under different forms of
protection over time. It is important to note that the Status Year is
only associated with the current designation and not the underlying
geographic area. For example, if a Game Reserve designated in 1990
changed status to National Park in 2005, the status year for the
National Park designation will be 2005 and the earlier Game Reserve will
no longer be in the WDPA.

\"\"\"

several PAs in Madagascar changed status, among others the historical
large Pas that were created as integral natural reserves (IUCN category
Ia) and converted to natural parks (IUCN category II), but this means
that many research that use this data.

The manual also mentions:

\"\"\"

Recommendations: The Status Year can be used to create graphs showing
designation of protected areas or OECMs over time. It cannot be used to
show historical change in protection over a geographic area, because
degazetted sites are removed from the databases (Lewis et al. 2017).
When the status year is not available, users can either exclude these
records from analyses or treat them as a baseline, i.e. the first year
of a temporal analysis (see UNEP-WCMC and IUCN 2016 for an example of
the latter). Trends analysis is also possible by assigning a status year
for a protected area based on pre-defined assumptions (see Butchart et
al. 2015).

Protected areas spatial data, which includes their location and
characteristics, is an essential source for conservation studies.
National and international databases that provide this information
typically include the current boundaries of protected areas, as well as
their attributes such as creation date, status, and manager. However,
this data structure results in a significant loss of information
regarding past states of protected areas when their boundaries or
characteristics have changed over time. This practice leads to erroneous
results when using the data to analyze the evolution of protected areas
or evaluate their impact on the environment and living conditions. It
also omits phenomena like degazetting, leading to previously existing
protected areas being treated as if they never existed.
